curriculumTitle: Sky High: Applied Drone Aviation & Engineering Curriculum (40-Minute Modular Format)
overview: A refined, modular STEM curriculum adapted for 40-minute instructional blocks, specifically designed for DOE TRIO programs in Texas. This course guides High School students from novice pilots to drone engineers through physics, Python coding, and mathematical application. It is strictly aligned with Texas TEKS, Texas STEM Frameworks, and DOE TRIO allowable services/costs, making it suitable for after-school, Saturday, or summer academy schedules in the DFW area.
prerequisites: Basic Algebra I proficiency; familiarity with Cartesian coordinate systems. No prior aviation or coding experience required.

fieldTrips.name: Hillwood AllianceTexas Mobility Innovation Zone (MIZ)
fieldTrips.description: A tour of the cutting-edge testing ground for aerial and surface mobility technology, observing commercial drone delivery testing and autonomous logistics.
fieldTrips.relevanceToCurriculum: Demonstrates real-world application of autonomous flight coding and logistics math discussed in Sessions 5, 6, 9, and 10.

fieldTrips.name: Bell Flight Experience Center
fieldTrips.description: An interactive facility showcasing vertical lift technology, including tiltrotor aircraft and future urban air mobility concepts.
fieldTrips.relevanceToCurriculum: Directly reinforces the 'Physics of Flight' (Session 1) and 'Engineering Design' (Session 7) by showing industrial application of vertical lift aerodynamics.

fieldTrips.name: Frontiers of Flight Museum
fieldTrips.description: A comprehensive aviation museum featuring history, rocketry, and STEM education labs focused on aerodynamics.
fieldTrips.relevanceToCurriculum: Provides historical context to the aerodynamic principles learned in Session 1 and offers exposure to varying aerospace careers.

activities.title: Session 1: The Physics of Flight & FAA Regulations
activities.description: An introductory classroom session focusing on the four forces of flight and the legal requirements for recreational flyers.
learningObjectives: Identify and explain Lift, Weight, Thrust, and Drag.
Understand FAA safety guidelines and the TRUST exam requirements.
Calculate the thrust-to-weight ratio necessary for takeoff.
teks: Physics 112.39(c)(4)(A): Generate and interpret graphs describing motion.
CTE 130.402(c)(8)(A): Identify and describe the forces of flight.

brief: Lab: Weigh drone and calculate thrust (15 min).
detailed: Minute 0-10: Lecture on Newtonâ€™s Third Law and propeller physics. Use the demo drone to show angle of attack.
Minute 10-25: Review FAA 'Recreational Flyer' rules and TRUST exam sample questions. Emphasize airspace safety.
Minute 25-40: Have students weigh the drone in grams, convert to Newtons, and calculate required thrust (>1.0 ratio).
Draw a free-body diagram showing the four forces (Lift vs. Weight, Thrust vs. Drag).
Weigh the drone to find the Force of Gravity (Weight) in Newtons.
Complete the practice FAA safety quiz to ensure understanding of legal flying zones.

trioCompliance.justification: Provides rigorous laboratory science instruction regarding physics and aerodynamics, a required service for UBMS.
heaRequirements: Sec. 402C(b) (UB Required Services): Academic instruction in science.
cfrCitations: 34 CFR 645.11(a)(1): Instruction in reading, writing, study skills, mathematics, laboratory science...
34 CFR 645.11(b)(1): Exposure to academic programs and careers.
edgarCitations: 2 CFR 200.453: Materials and supplies costs, including computing devices.

activities.title: Session 2-3: Flight Boot Camp (Manual Control)
activities.description: A double-block lab session where students master manual flight controls through specific safety drills and maneuvers.
learningObjectives: Demonstrate mastery of roll, pitch, yaw, and throttle.
Execute a 4-point box maneuver maintaining constant altitude.
teks: Physics 112.39(c)(4)(C): Analyze accelerated motion in two dimensions.
CTE 130.402(c)(10)(B): Demonstrate use of precision instruments.
texasStemStandards: STEM Fluency Skill: Critical Thinking and Problem Solving

brief: Session 2: Hover drills and safety checks.
Session 3: Lateral movement and Box Pattern test.
detailed: Session 2 (0-40): Demonstrate pre-flight checklist. Conduct 'Hover Drills' (waist height only). Ensure students keep tails-in orientation.
Session 3 (40-80): Introduce lateral movement (Roll). Guide students through the 'Box Pattern' drill: Forward, Right, Back, Left.
Complete pre-flight checklist (props secure, battery charged).
Practice 'Throttle only' to maintain steady hover at waist height.
Fly the 'Box Pattern': Forward 1m, Right 1m, Back 1m, Left 1m.
Log flight time and battery voltage usage in flight journal.

trioCompliance.justification: Hands-on laboratory science experience reinforcing physics concepts of motion and control.
cfrCitations: 34 CFR 645.12: Upward Bound Math and Science projects must provide intensive instruction in math and science.

activities.title: Session 4: Introduction to Drone Coding (Python/Blocks)
activities.description: Students transition from manual flight to computational thinking, mapping the 3D coordinate plane to code commands.
learningObjectives: Apply geometric concepts (X, Y, Z axes) to drone navigation.
Write a basic flight script: Takeoff, Hover, Land.
Understand the difference between open-loop and closed-loop control.
teks: CompSci 126.33(c)(5)(A): Develop algorithms to solve a problem.
Geometry 111.41(c)(3)(A): Describe transformations in a plane.

detailed: Minute 0-15: Teach the coordinate plane relative to the drone (Pitch=Y, Roll=X, Throttle=Z). Use physical hand gestures.
Minute 15-30: Demonstrate basic commands in the IDE/Python interface (e.g., drone.takeoff()).
Minute 30-40: Students write their first 'Hello World' flight script (Takeoff > Sleep(5) > Land).
Open the coding interface and connect to the simulator.
Map out the X (Left/Right), Y (Forward/Back), and Z (Up/Down) directions.
Write a script to: Takeoff, Sleep(5), Land.
Simulate the code before executing on hardware.

trioCompliance.justification: Explicit instruction in Mathematics (Geometry) and Computer Science, fulfilling core curriculum requirements.
cfrCitations: 34 CFR 645.11(b)(6): Instruction in alternative education programs (computer science).
edgarCitations: 2 CFR 200.454: Memberships, subscriptions, and professional activity costs (Software licenses).

activities.title: Session 5-6: The Autonomous Maze Challenge
activities.description: A double-block session where students measure a physical environment and write code to navigate it without human intervention.
learningObjectives: Utilize loops and variables to automate flight paths.
Measure physical distances and convert to code parameters.
Debug code by analyzing flight failures.

brief: Session 6: Code input, testing, debugging, final run.
detailed: Session 5 (0-40): Layout floor maze using tape. Have students measure distances in centimeters and 'pseudocode' the path on paper.
Session 6 (40-80): Students input code, test flights, adjust parameters (debugging) for drift, and run for final success.
Map the obstacle course on graph paper.
Calculate distances (cm) and rotations (degrees) needed.
Write the script using loops for repetitive movements (e.g., 'for i in range(4)').
Run the code; if it crashes, measure the error and adjust the values.

trioCompliance.justification: Applies geometry and measurement standards in a technology-rich environment.
cfrCitations: 34 CFR 645.11(b)(1): Exposure to academic programs and careers.

activities.title: Session 7: Payload Engineering - Design & Prototype
activities.description: Students apply the engineering design process to create a hook or basket mechanism for the drone.
learningObjectives: Apply the Engineering Design Process (Ask, Imagine, Plan).
teks: CTE 130.362(c)(6)(D): Develop a prototype using available materials.
Physics 112.39(c)(4)(D): Calculate the effect of forces.
texasStemStandards: STEM Fluency Skill: Creativity and Innovation

brief: Explain payload scenario and CG (10 min).
detailed: Minute 0-10: Explain the problem (Search & Rescue Delivery) and Center of Gravity constraints. Show examples of unbalanced loads.
Minute 10-30: Students sketch designs and build rapid prototypes using craft materials.
Minute 30-40: Initial fit-check on drones (no flight yet). Check for sensor blockage.
Sketch a lightweight carrier design.
Ensure the design does not block the downward sensors or interfere with props.
Build the prototype using minimal material to save weight.

trioCompliance.justification: Pure engineering lab activity aligning with UBMS goals for postsecondary engineering preparation.
cfrCitations: 34 CFR 645.11(b)(5): Mentoring programs involving elementary or secondary school teachers or other qualified individuals.

activities.title: Session 8: Payload Engineering - Testing & Data Analysis
activities.description: Students flight-test their prototypes with weights, recording data on stability and battery drain.
learningObjectives: Test and Improve prototypes based on performance.
Collect and analyze data (Weight vs. Flight Time).
teks: Math 111.43(c)(4): Use regression methods to describe data.

detailed: Minute 0-5: Safety briefing (heavy drones fall faster; stay clear).
Minute 5-30: Teams rotate through the flight cage, adding weight in increments.
Minute 30-40: Students graph their results (Weight on X-axis, Time on Y-axis) to find relationships.
Test 1: Hover with empty carrier. Record time to 50% battery.
Test 2: Add 10g. Record stability and battery drop.
Test 3: Add 20g. Repeat.
Graph the data to find the 'Critical Failure Point' where flight becomes unstable.

trioCompliance.justification: Data collection and analysis lab fitting Math and Science components.
heaRequirements: Sec. 402C(b): Instruction in mathematics and science.

activities.title: Session 9-10: Search & Rescue Math Olympics
activities.description: A capstone double-block where students solve math problems derived from live telemetry to locate targets and complete a course.
learningObjectives: Calculate velocity given distance and time.
teks: Physics 112.39(c)(4)(B): Analyze motion in one dimension.
Math 111.39(c)(1)(E): Solve systems of linear equations.
texasStemStandards: STEM Fluency Skill: Resilience and Adaptability

brief: Session 9: Scenario explanation and math planning.
detailed: Session 9 (0-40): Explain the SAR scenario. Teams plan their search grids and calculate area coverage requirements based on battery life.
Session 10 (40-80): The Competition. Teams fly the course. To pass a gate, they must pause and solve a math problem based on their flight data (e.g., speed calc).
Calculate total search area and required speed to cover it before battery death.
Fly the mission through the gates.
At the checkpoint, pause and calculate your average velocity (v=d/t) to get the pass code to proceed.

trioCompliance.justification: Gamifies instruction in Mathematics, increasing engagement while rigorously testing academic standards.
edgarCitations: 2 CFR 200.421: Advertising and public relations (allows for program outreach/nominal awards in some contexts, consult local OSP).
